text: [Music]
well you touching on a subject very near
and dear to me when I first came to
Harvard there was a great Professor here
still uh prowling the grounds named
Walter Jackson bait a name which may
ring true to you uh his his specialty
was the age of Samuel Johnson and he
wrote a great biography of Dr Johnson
which was quite a hit in the early 70s
and in it he discovered Johnson that uh
18th century uh dictionary man had a
list of three favorite books and it
happened to me that I had read all three
of those books and they were my favorite
books so I thought I was in very good
company with do Johnson and Professor
Walter Jackson B the three books were
svant Don
kiot uh defos uh Robinson cruso and uh
John bunan Pilgrims Progress I had read
all three of them and I loved how
Johnson described
his capacity to return to these books
for new material uh all of the time I
loved the idealism of Don kot the man
who could make the most ordinary things
appear to be beautiful
uh for whom windmills represented
opportunities for Challenge and change
uh fighting them and uh who traveled
across uh with his idealism more or less
intact living in his own world in the
middle of a reality that was not uh
supportive of his ideals I like that and
then I love uh uh Robinson cruso because
I love the the notion of shipwreck and
Improv ation having you create your own
world out of the ruins of another world
that was a wonderfully appealing sort of
sense of adventure and it even has a
diversity in it my man Friday I we've
all been aided by somebody we least
expected there was something very
exciting about taking that stuff off The
Old Ship and creating a new civilization
and not having to go back to the old
world out of which he had come and then
of course coming from Plymouth I loved
John bunan and the Pilgrim's Progress
the man with the book on his back a
great Baptist the sense of a purposeful
Journey long before Rick Warren ever
came along I rather enjoy this notion
that we're not just lost and wandering
tourists we are people with a
destination and we go through the slau
of the spawn and we pass through Vanity
Fair and we deal with all of these uh
terrible struggles because we are meant
for the celestial City so it was
wonderful to see that Dr Johnson took
great comfort from these three books
because I always did and contined to do
so so that's an example of the sort of
thing that the Western Cannon much NE
despised and neglected in these parts
has done for me it's given me a
vocabulary a set of images a world into
which I could go I was an Avid Reader as
a young boy I read everything I could
get my hands on I got all the little
prizes in school for reading the most
books in the summer and my name is still
on a little tablet in the children's
room in the public library because I
could consume vast quantities of those
orange backed books I loved biography
and I had a I had a fertile imagination
I could live in the world of other
people and to those substantial books I
added such wonderful Treasures as uh
allice and Wonderland and uh The Wind
and The Willows where I always imagined
myself to be Mr Toad putting around uh
in a yellow motor
uh there was a whole world that in my
little town of Plymouth uh was not off
limits to me because it was the world of
books and ideas and all of those have
fed into my
imagination and uh I think that enriches
and stimulates my preaching and my my
teaching
